basics.name: Temitope Adeoye
basics.summary: Applying systems biology methods in biophysics and genomics to better understand dysfunction in neurological disorders.

education.area: Applied Physics: Computational Biophysics and Neurobiology
Applied Physics: Computational Biophysics and Neurobiology

work.name: Computational Biophysics Group, University of South Florida
work.summary: Primary research has focused on applying theoretical and computational techniques as well as single-cell multi-omics to understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms of synaptic dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). This has involved investigating neuronal signaling pathways and gene programs affected in AD and their impact on synaptic plasticity. These research experiences have resulted in two publications and multiple collaborations.

work.name: Cajal Neuroscience
work.summary: My work here focused on developing deep learning pipelines for mapping and contextualizing single-cell sequencing data to aid rapid integration of new datasets into reference atlases. The project involved implementing an interpretable deep learning approach with explainable embeddings to create biologically informed latent representations, and deploying standardized bioinformatic workflows to identify cell states, differential expression patterns, and trajectories in Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease (PD) models.

work.name: University of South Florida
work.summary: Investigated the role of intrinsic disorder in Ebola and Marburg virus proteins and its potential implications for virulence.

awards.title: Trainee Professional Development Award
awards.summary: This award is given to graduate students who demonstrate scientific merit and excellence in research.

awards.title: Tharp and Duckwall Summer Research Fellowship
awards.awarder: College of Arts and Sciences, University of South Florida
awards.summary: This is awarded in recognition of accomplishments as a graduate student and in support of continuing research and scholarship activities.

awards.title: University of Lagos Endowment Prize
awards.summary: This award is given to students who maintain a GPA of 4.5 and above (3.6 on a 4.0 scale) in each semester.

awards.title: Dean's Award
awards.summary: Honors recognizing the best graduating student from the program, the Department of Physics

publications-hhh.name: Systematic Analysis of Biological Processes Reveals Gene Co-expression Modules Driving Pathway Dysregulation in Alzheimer’s Disease.
publications-hhh.summary: We integrate pathway activity analysis with weighted gene co-expression patterns to provide insights into the functional coherence and interplay among genes involved in perturbed biological processes in AD.

publications-hhh.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications-hhh.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications-hhh.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications-hhh.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
